__data__.text:
Object-Oriented
Programming
PROJECT
REPORT
Tic-Tac-Toe
By
Piyush
Modi
-
200907056
Sagnik
Biswas
-
200907098
Thrisha
Sammidi
-
200907260
Ananya
Maansingh
-
200907124
Pr oject
Ov er view:
The
project
is
a
console-based
implementation
of
the
classic
Tic-Tac-Toe
game.
It
allows
two
players
('X'
and
'O')
to
take
turns
making
moves
on
a
3x3
grid
until
one
of
them
wins,
or
the
game
ends
in
a
draw.
The
code
uses
multiple
object-oriented
programming
concepts
to
structure
the
game.
FISAC
1
OOP
Concepts
Used
:
1.
Classes
:
The
code
deﬁnes
two
main
classes,
`Board`
and
`Player`,
to
model
the
game.
These
classes
encapsulate
the
game's
state
and
behavior.
2.
Construct or
and
Destructor:
Both
the
`Board`
and
`Player`
classes
have
construct ors
and
destructors.
Construct ors
initialize
the
objects,
while
destructors
are
used
to
clean
up
resources
when
objects
are
destroyed.
3.
Member
Functions
:
Member
functions
are
used
to
deﬁne
the
behavior
of
objects.
Functions
like
`Play(),`
`checkWin(),`
and
`dispCoor ds()`
are
member
functions
of
the
`Player`
class.
4.
Data
Encapsulation
:
The
code
encapsulates
data
within
classes.
For
example,
the
game
board
is
stored
as
a
private
member
of
the
`Board`
class,
and
player-related
information
is
stored
within
the
`Player`
class.
5.
Operator
Overloading
:
The
code
overloads
the
`<<`
operator
to
print
the
Tic-Tac-Toe
board,
enhancing
the
readability
of
the
code.
6.
Static
Data
Members
:
The
`num_steps`
variable
is
declared
as
a
static
data
member,
shared
among
all
instances
of
the
`Player`
class.

7.
Passing
Objects
as
Parameters
:
Objects
of
the
`Board`
class
are
passed
as
parameters
to
member
functions
of
the
`Player`
class
to
update
and
manipulate
the
game
state.
8.
Construct or
Overloading
:
The
`Player`
class
has
multiple
construct ors,
demonstr ating
construct or
overloading.
Logic
Explanation:
1.
Board
Class
:
-
The
`Board`
class
represents
the
game
board,
which
is
a
3x3
grid.
-
It
dynamically
allocates
memory
for
the
board
in
the
construct or
and
deallocates
it
in
the
destructor.
-
The
`<<`
operator
is
overloaded
to
print
the
board.
2.
Player
Class
:
-
The
`Player`
class
represents
a
player
in
the
game.
-
It
has
construct ors
to
initialize
player
information
and
reset
game
statistics.
-
The
`Play()`
method
allows
players
to
make
moves,
checks
for
valid
moves,
updates
the
board,
and
checks
for
a
win
or
draw.
-
The
`checkWin()`
method
checks
if
a
player
has
won
by
examining
rows,
columns,
and
diagonals.
-
The
`dispCoor ds()`
method
displays
the
row
and
column
numbers
to
assist
players
in
making
moves.
-
The
`reset_num_steps()`
method
resets
the
number
of
steps
in
the
game.
-
The
`checkMatchOv er()`
method
checks
if
the
match
is
over
and
provides
feedback.

FISAC
2
OOP
Concepts
Used
Title:
Object-Oriented
Programming
(OOP)
Concepts
in
a
Tic-Tac-Toe
C++
Project
1.
Inheritance:
-
Inheritance
is
a
fundamental
OOP
concept
used
in
the
project.
-
`Game`,
`player_x`,
and
`player_o`
classes
are
derived
from
the
`Board`
class,
demonstr ating
the
concept
of
inheritance.
-
The
`Game`
class
inherits
from
the
`Board`
class,
which
means
it
inherits
the
properties
and
methods
of
the
base
class.
-
The
Display_Board
class
is
an
abstract
class.
It
has
pure
virtual
functions
which
are
deﬁned
in
the
Board
class.

1.1.
Multi-level
Inheritance:
-
Multilevel
inheritance
is
exempliﬁed
through
the
relationship
between
the
`TicTacToe`
class
and
the
`Game`
class.
The
`TicTacToe`
class
serves
as
a
derived
class
of
the
`Game`
class,
which,
in
turn,
inherits
from
the
`Board`
class.
This
forms
a
multilevel
inheritance
chain
where
the
TicTacToe
class
inherits
properties
and
behaviors
from
both
the
Game
and
Board
classes
1.2.
Multiple
Inheritance:
-
Multiple
inheritance,
on
the
other
hand,
is
exhibited
in
the
relationship
between
the
`player_x`
and
`player_o`
classes,
which
both
inherit
from
the
`Game`
class.
Additionally ,
the
`Game`
class
uses
protected
inheritance
from
the
`Board`
class.
This
combination
of
inheritance
types
creates
a
hierarchy
where
the
`player_x`
and
`player_o`
classes
inherit
attributes
and
methods
from
the
`Game`
class
while
the
`Game`
class,
in
turn,
inherits
features
from
the
`Board`
class.
This
results
in
a
form
of
multiple
inheritance,
allowing
classes
to
inherit
from
more
than
one
base
class,
albeit
in
a
controlled
manner
through
virtual
inheritance
in
this
code.
2.
Polymorphism:
-
Polymorphism
is
another
key
OOP
concept
employed
in
the
project.
-
Function
overriding
and
overloading
are
used
to
achieve
polymorphism.
-
The
`update`
function
in
the
`Game`
class
for
player_o
demonstr ates
function
overriding,
as
it
overrides
the
base
class
function.
This
has
overridden
the
Game
class’
update
function.
-
Function
overloading
is
used
in
the
`player_x`
class
by
providing
an
additional
parameter
to
the
`update`
function.
3.
Abstraction
:
-
The
project
employs
abstraction
to
hide
complex
implementation
details.
-
The
project
employs
abstraction
to
hide
complex
implementation
details.
-
Abstract
classes
and
pure
virtual
functions
are
used
to
create
a
framework
for
the
game.
-
The
abstract
class
is
Display_Board,
with
two
pure
virtual
functions
disp_boar d()
and
disp_coor ds().

4.
Encapsulation:
-
Encapsulation
is
applied
to
restrict
access
to
certain
members
of
the
classes.
-
Data
members
of
classes
are
declared
as
private
or
protected
to
encapsulate
them
from
direct
external
access.
-
Member
functions
are
used
to
interact
with
and
modify
these
data
members.
-
The
protected
members
in
the
abstract
class
Display_Board
are
the
moves
pointer
which
is
initialized
as
a
string,
count
and
the
constant
integer
size.
-
The
protected
members
in
the
Board
class
are
the
integer
pos,
the
pointer
q,
and
the
currPlayer
char.
The
advantage
of
using
protected
members
are
that
they
are
accessible
to
any
friend
or
member
function
of
a
derived
class.
Thus,
fulﬁlling
the
purpose
of
encapsulation
while
sharing
data.
-
Private
members
restrict
direct
external
access
for
data
encapsulation
and
controlled
behavior,
while
public
members
provide
external
interfaces
for
interaction,
enhancing
encapsulation
and
maintaining
security.
5.
Dynamically
Allocated
Memory:
-
The
project
demonstr ates
the
concept
of
dynamic
memory
allocation
by
using
the
`new`
and
`delete`
operators.
-
The
`moves`
array
in
the
`Board`
class
is
dynamically
allocated
and
released
using
`delete`
in
the
destructor
to
avoid
memory
leaks.
6.
Construct ors
and
Destructors:
-
Construct ors
are
used
to
initialize
objects
when
they
are
created.
-
base
class
pointer,
ob,
is
declared
and
then
assigned
to
point
to
a
derived
class
object,
ob1,
which
is
an
instance
of
the
player_o
class.
This
demonstr ates
polymorphism,
as
a
base
class
pointer
can
be
used
to
refer
to
derived
class
objects.
-
The
project
employs
construct ors
to
initialize
class
members
and
allocate
resources.
-
The
`Board`
class
uses
an
initializer
list
in
its
construct or
to
set
the
`size`
member.
-
The
`Game`
class,
as
the
central
class
responsible
for
managing
the
game's
logic,
implements
a
virtual
destructor.

7.
Virtual
Functions
and
Polymorphic
Behavior:
-
Virtual
functions
allow
the
derived
classes
to
provide
their
own
implementation.
-
The
`display()`
function
is
a
virtual
function
in
the
`Board`
class,
allowing
it
to
be
overridden
by
the
`Game`
class
to
provide
polymorphic
behavior.
-
The
use
of
a
virtual
destructor
in
the
`Game`
class
ensures
that
resources
are
properly
released
when
objects
of
derived
classes
are
destroyed.
-
A
pure
virtual
function
is
a
virtual
function
that
is
required
to
be
implemented
by
a
derived
class
if
the
derived
class
is
not
abstract.
-
disp_boar d
and
disp_coor ds
are
pure
virtual
functions
that
are
deﬁned
within
the
Board
class
which
displays
the
value
of
each
cell
of
the
board
and
displays
its
coordinates,
respectively.
-
This
code
represents
the
two
players,
X
and
O,
as
virtual
base
classes
player_x,
and
player_o.
8.
Member
Access
Control:
-
The
project
demonstr ates
the
access
control
levels
of
public,
private,
and
protected.
-
Class
members
are
declared
as
private,
protected,
or
public
based
on
their
intended
access
levels.
-
The
`Game`
class
accesses
protected
members
of
the
`Board`
class.
9.
Game
Flow:
-
The
`TicTacToe`
class
encapsulates
the
game's
logic,
including
player
turns
and
win
conditions.
-
It
orchestrates
the
game
ﬂow,
validating
moves,
and
checking
for
a
win
or
draw.
-
Input
and
output
are
managed
through
the
standard
input
and
output
streams.
Conclusion
The
C++
Tic-Tac-Toe
project
effectively
applies
fundamental
OOP
concepts,
including
inheritance,
polymorphism,
abstraction,
encapsulation,
and
more.
These
principles
contribute
to
a
well-structur ed
and
extensible
codebase,
enabling
easy
expansion
and
maintenance
of
the
game.
The
project
showcases
the
power
of
OOP
in
software
design
and
development.
